thread.title: England hopes fade in Dubai as Pakistan build ominous advantage
thread.title_full: England hopes fade in Dubai as Pakistan build ominous advantage

title: England hopes fade in Dubai as Pakistan build ominous advantage
text:
England hopes fade in Dubai as Pakistan build ominous advantage 25 Oct 2015 08:17:00 
comments 
England's faint hopes of saving the second Test receded further as Younus Khan carried Pakistan to a mammoth lead of 447 on the fourth morning in Dubai. 
Younus (112 not out) lost his overnight partner Misbah-ul-Haq early, the captain missing his chance of a second century in the match for the second time in his career when - as in the first innings - he fell without addition on the resumption. 
But Pakistan's all-time record run scorer was unfazed by that on the way to a hundred of his own, his 31st, as the hosts moved from 222 for three to 311 for four. 
James Anderson broke the fourth-wicket stand on 141 in the fourth over of the day when Misbah (87) mistimed his slower off-cutter straight into the hands of mid-off. 
England's task was not significantly eased, however, and remained unenviable as they waited for the inevitable moment when they must bat last here. 
Their target will be notional - higher than any achieved in Test history, let alone at this venue where the spin of Yasir Shah is sure to make mere survival a mission improbable. 
Younus completed his century with his 11th four, a back-foot force off Adil Rashid, from 193 balls - in an unbroken stand of 87 with Asad Shafiq. 
All the while, Misbah was free to calculate at his leisure how much more energy he could make England expend in the field and how long Pakistan might need to bowl them out to go 1-0 up with one to play. 
England unsurprisingly declined the availability of a second new ball, choosing a lack of pace rather than any acceleration of their likely fate. Related Sport News
